14/ These #cryptoasset forks = "allopatric speciation." Once separated, the communities will evolve independently & determine their own fate
13/ How value plays out in the *long-term* for #cryptoassets and their forks will all boil down to *long-term* governance.
12/ Important for us to remember #cryptoassets connect humans just as much as they connect machines. Governance is the new defensible asset.
11/ In #cryptonetworks, the square of the number of users connected in a network is only valuable if they are cohesively governed.
10/ It is this matter of #cryptoasset governance that allows value creation after forks to buck Metcalfe's Law.
9/ $ETC holds only a fraction (3.5%) of $ETH's value b/c it has a much smaller community w/ fewer constituents & less faith in the governors
8/ It was only once the drama started to settle down and governance tightened up that #Ethereum hit its stride, going ~30x in 2017.
7/ I would argue $ETH's initial value destruction after the fork is b/c the community was in turmoil, and $ETC hardly had a community
6/ When #Ethereum forked in July 2016, it was around $12 per $ETH & proceeded to lose 50% of its value by December 2016. Value destruction.
5/ Compare the immediate value creation after #Bitcoin's Aug 2017 fork with #Ethereum's July 2016 fork to navigate around #TheDAO
4/ $BCH remains a fraction (~5%) of $BTC because its governors are less functional & show less promise to innovate & protect their community
3/ The split of $BTC and $BCH allowed #Bitcoin's governance to be more cohesive, hence we saw #bitcoin explode in value (up ~3x since)
2/ When #Bitcoin forked into $BTC & $BCH, governance went from 2 warring parties in 1 community, to 2 communities with ~1 party each
1/ Contentious #cryptoasset forks represent a divergence in governance, outcome depends on how cohesively the 2 resulting communities evolve

3/ Contrast the #ICO model w/ mining. Thru mining, #tokens are minted & distributed to people who provide underlying utility to the network
2/ Reason being, #ICOs distribute to whoever has the dollars (or similar) to pay. These holders provide little core utility to the network.

@SlackHQ 10/ ...or the #crypto devs getting flooded with emails from hyperventilating speculators "crowds out" dev time & energy.
9/ eg, a @SlackHQ channel that was once filled with people geeking out on the #tech then getting flooded w/ speculators is a "crowding out"
8/ Beyond the pricing of the #cryptoasset, there are fuzzier ways speculators crowd out utilizers, which are harder to solve.
7/ Hence, if 2-tier pricing is fluid enough (#Ethereum has some work left to do), it can better keep the speculators & utilizers both happy
6/ A deflationary #cryptoasset, or perhaps better thought of as a cryptoasset that grows in purchasing power, is a good store of value.
5/ Take a storage coin, for example. Price of coin goes up in $, but *$ per GB* to store files stays flat. Coin becomes deflationary.
4/ Hence, w/ 2-tier speculators can bid up the asset, while cost per unit of the resource provisioned by the underlying #blockchain is ~flat
3/ To solve pricing problem, a 2-tier model makes sense, where the price of the asset is divorced from the pricing of the underlying utility
2/ "Speculators" crowding out "utilizers" relevant not just 2 price of the #cryptoasset, but also things like dev time, community focus, etc
1/ Speculation = üí∞¬†foundation for innovation, but #crypto systems also need 2 be designed 2 ensure "speculators" don't crowd out "utilizers"

15/ Extra value & margin left in the #cryptoasset will be driven by SoV HODLers, and they will drive investment & security in the network
14/ but suffice to say, MoE being driven to infinite velocity will commoditize most provisioning of digital resources
13/ I don't want to go down the vulnerability and security rabbit hole because that leads to a whole different consideration of "utility"
12/ that cryptoasset could continue to serve its MoE use case with very little value stored in the network, so long as it's not vulnerable
11/ With overall velocity going up, if the demand 4 the asset is also not increasing, then the price and network value of the #crypto will üìâ
10/ Could lead 2 viscious unwinds in #cryptoasset values if SoV holders largely lose faith. Velocities of 1 will be lost, overall V goes up
9/ MoE velocity will be pushed towards infinity by the mkt (given low latency doesn't compromise security or similar), while SoV stays at 1
8/ Hence, the overall #cryptoasset's velocity becomes a hybrid of the velocity and % share of the asset being used for MoE vs SoV
7/ A "store of value" holder induces a velocity of 1 on that #cryptoasset for the units that they hold in this way for the entire year
6/ HODLers will keep the #cryptoasset close if they believe in future growth of the utility value of that asset, which is the SoV use case
5/ High velocity for the means of exchange role of a #cryptoasset doesn't necessarily mean high overall velocity, which is where SoV enters
4/ I think this means of exchange role for a #cryptoasset will trend towards less & less latency, and hence a higher velocity
3/ The "means of exchange" role for a #cryptoasset uses the underlying protocol to exchange value for the "goods & services" of the network
2/ I say this despite still mentally segmenting #cryptoasset taxonomy into 3 buckets: #cryptocurrencies, #cryptocommodities & #cryptotokens
1/ Each #cryptoasset is a currency in its own private economy, serving means of exchange, store of value, and unit of account roles

7/ Did some work w/ @RyanRadloff on evolution of oil markets & derivatives. While they are created after the underlying (duh), derivs can..
6/ Liquidity: derivatives can be more liquid than the underlying. For institutions wanting to put billions to work, this is vital 4 #bitcoin
5/ The risk is one that risk committees know how to analyze, and will likely allow them to get comfortable w/ #bitcoin exposure more quickly
4/ Counterparty risk then becomes reliant on financial stability of derivative issuer. While this is a bit backwards from #bitcoin's ethos..
3/ For a number of derivatives they don't need to be backed by the underlying asset. This means there is no underlying #bitcoin to be hacked
2/ Counterparties: many institutions struggle w/ the idea of #bitcoin custody. With derivatives, the counterparty is a *less foreign* beast

10/ In short, I always end up at the same place. We need #bitcoin to both serve as a solid MoE *and* SoV to achieve the long term üåç vision.
9/ With lower hash rate per $$$ stored, my concern then becomes if as many people will trust #bitcoin as a reliable store of value.
8/ If the $$$ is not enough to sustain a robust base of miners, then #Bitcoin's legendary security will slowly fade.
7/ If transaction volumes are low, then no matter how high value those txn's are, I worry about if the $$$ will be enough 4 #bitcoin miners
6/ Long run, newly minted #bitcoin must be supplanted entirely by transaction fees to sustain miners & achieve 0% rate of supply inflation.

9/ Miners are likely aware of this inevitability, but it still doesn't mean they'll use their position to usher in L2
8/ However, L2 solutions *will* happen regardless. LN & more possible w/o Segwit. Demand and solutions for L2 will route around obstacles
7/ As a result, I don‚Äôt expect HF over current issue (which is much riskier than Segwit SF). Instead, expect status quo to continue.
6/ If L2 isn‚Äôt immediately additive, they mightn‚Äôt survive to see LT benefits. Consequently, miner incentive to preserve status quo.
5/ Even if miners believe L2 solutions will benefit them, nobody *knows* exactly how it will play out, thus to miners it is uncertainty/risk
4/ Mining margins are thin, adding uncertainty/risk can shift expected profitability from positive to negative.
3/ In contrast, miners buy equipment with a 6-18 month horizon before obsolescence. Need to recoup costs & generate return.
2/ Most ecosystem businesses and hodlers have a longer horizon and positioned for major growth over next 3,5,10  years
1/ Regarding ongoing conflict with miners, time horizon is a major source of difference that is illuminating in understanding the conflict.

@lightcoin The argument being made is that somehow Segwit's rule is weaker or less valid than any other consensus r‚Ä¶ https://t.co/1FeuDBoO7N
@lightcoin That applies to any rule. Any rule can be changed by a hard fork. You can make the block reward 150 BTC.‚Ä¶ https://t.co/0RHSbsRghu
@SimonDingle Because this misunderstanding of "AnyoneCanSpend" has spread and is held by many. It is worth discussi‚Ä¶ https://t.co/RjeNLSOEqn
Miners don't make the rules, they don't validate alone. It takes 5 constituencies of consensus to validate the rules. They can't go it alone
If miners could do that, they could revert back to revert P2SH and spend all those coins (whatever % have shown the RedeemScript previously)
Consensus rules are not a cafeteria menu, where the miners can choose to revert back to an older version and revert a soft fork.
Or that it is somehow less of a rule than "You must also satisfy the Redeem Script, not just present it" in P2SH
Wright is essentially saying that the 51% miners will break that rule, as if it is less of a rule than "you need a signature to spend P2PKH"
If Segwit has been activated, the new rules are followed by everyone. Under those new rules to spend a Segwit UTXO you must satisfy witness
Any rule can be ignored by 51% of the miners, but would make that chain invalid in the eyes of everyone else. Ignoring Segwit is no diff
A P2SH scriptPub only requires presentation of a RedeemScript, unless everyone validates so that the RedeemScript must also be satisfied.
By the exact same logic, 51% of the miners could mine a chain spending Satoshi's block#0 reward with the sig "Deez Nuts". We'd all reject it
I disagree with Craig Wright about Segwit. The exact same risk could be said to exist with P2SH. Neither can be exploited with a 51% attack
@nandubatchu No. There's no such thing really as anyonecanspend. 51% attacks could spend anything anytime. Except e‚Ä¶ https://t.co/q7nYQKtZtF

RT @simondlr: Packed #ethereum Cape Town meetup tonight with @avsa & @aantonop! See you all later!

‚ö°Ô∏è ‚ÄúBugs happen. QA is what stops them from going into production‚Äù

https://t.co/GT2yUwcxVd
</tweetstorm>
This time there was little economic impact. During a fork, the damage would have been in the millions. QA matters. It matters $millions
Ironically, some are outraged that exploit code was used to attack BU nodes. Consider if this code was held back until 20 blocks into a fork
To fix a QA process that is 1000x less effective at catching bugs, you'd need devs who are 1000x better at coding - those don't exist
BU has shipped an exploitable bug on a code base that is 0.001 of the size of Core's. That's several orders of magnitude worse QA process
Core's QA process & team review has managed to deliver tens of thousands of changes without an exploit like this in production.
It's not about preventing bugs from being written. It's about preventing them from going into production. That takes a TEAM & a PROCESS
Blaming this on "incompetence" of BU devs misses the point & undervalues the invisible but highly effective QA process that Core offers
The whole system works to be able to produce large volume of quality production code, even when not all the contributors are "dream team"
This is not the result (only) of competent devs. It is review, diverse skills, test coverage & a large user base testing release candidates
Bugs like this pop up in Core code too. The important difference: they *never* make it to production releases. The QA process catches them
If you depend on every dev being a "dream team", you can't scale. It takes a diverse team to be able to produce quality code, consistently
BU bug: This isn't about individual competence. It's about a process with diverse and laborious review, which catches bugs before production
